DOCNAME: CASE OF SAVEZ CRKAVA "RIJEC ZIVOTA" AND OTHERS v. CROATIA
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Art. 14+9;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants are churches of a Reformist denomination which are registered as religious communities under NORP law and which have their seats in GPE ( the first and second applicant churches ) and ORG the third applicant church ) .

CARDINAL . The first applicant church has been present in GPE since DATE , the second since DATE and the third since DATE as part of ORG and since DATE as an independent church . The applicant churches were entered in the register of religious communities in GPE on DATE ( the first applicant church ) , DATE ( the second applicant church ) and DATE ( the third applicant church ) , in accordance with LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant churches submitted a request to ORG for Relations with Religious Communities ( ORG za odnose s vjerskim zajednicama – “ ORG ” ) in order to conclude an agreement with ORG , as envisaged in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , which would regulate their relations with the State . They explained that without such an agreement they were unable to provide religious education in public schools and nurseries , to provide pastoral care to their members in medical and social - welfare institutions , as well to those in prisons and penitentiaries , or to perform religious marriages with the effects of a civil marriage .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Government of GPE adopted an instruction ( zaključak CARDINAL “ the Instruction ” ) setting out the criteria which religious communities had to satisfy in order to conclude such an agreement with it ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG informed the applicant churches that they did not satisfy , either individually or jointly , the historical and numerical criteria set out in the above Instruction , that is to say , that they had not been present in the territory of GPE since DATE and that the number of their adherents did not exceed CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . Referring to section QUANTITY of the DATE LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and sections DATE ) and CARDINAL of ORG Sentences Act ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) , it also remarked that members of religious communities which had not concluded the relevant agreement with ORG had a right to receive pastoral care in medical and social - welfare institutions as well as in prisons and penitentiaries .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant churches submitted another request to conclude an appropriate agreement with ORG , this time addressing it to the Prime Minister directly .

CARDINAL . In a letter of DATE ORG replied to the applicant churches’ request of DATE , informing them again that they did not satisfy , either individually or jointly , the criteria set forth in the Instruction of DATE , this time without specifying which particular criteria had not been met . It again referred to section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW and sections DATE ) and CARDINAL of ORG , reiterating its opinion that the members of religious communities which had not concluded appropriate agreements with ORG had a right to receive pastoral care in medical and social - welfare institutions and in prisons and penitentiaries .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant churches then lodged a request for the protection of a constitutionally guaranteed right ( zahtjev za zaštitu ustavom zajamčenog prava ) with ORG ( Upravni sud PERSON ) against ORG refusal of DATE , in accordance with section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . They argued that the refusal , even though it had been given in the form of a letter , constituted “ an individual legal act ” ( that is , a decision ) , within the meaning of section CARDINAL of LAW , that had violated their constitutional right to equality of all religious communities before the law , as guaranteed by LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared their action inadmissible , holding that ORG refusal did not constitute “ an individual act ” for the purposes of CARDINAL of LAW , and thus was not susceptible to that court ’s review .

CARDINAL . The applicant churches then lodged a constitutional complaint , relying again , inter alia , on LAW and alleging a violation of their constitutional right to equality of all religious communities before the law . On DATE ORG ( Ustavni sud PERSON ) dismissed the applicant churches’ constitutional complaint , finding , inter alia , that LAW was not applicable in the particular case .

CARDINAL . Sections CARDINAL provide for special proceedings for the protection of constitutionally guaranteed rights and freedoms from unlawful factual ( physical ) acts of public authorities , if no other judicial remedy is available . Under the case - law of the domestic courts , the protection against unlawful “ acts ” also includes omissions ( for example , ORG in its decision no . Us-CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE and ORG in its decision no . Gž-CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE held that failure of the administrative authorities to carry out their own enforcement order constituted an “ unlawful act ” within the meaning of CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides that such proceedings are to be instituted by bringing an “ action against an unlawful act ” ( tužba za zaštitu od nezakonite radnje ) in the competent municipal court . The action must be brought against the public authority to which the factual act ( or omission ) is imputable ( the defendant ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides that the court decides on the merits of the case by a judgment . If it finds in favour of the plaintiff , the court orders the defendant to desist from the unlawful activity and , if necessary , orders restitutio in integrum .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides that in proceedings following an “ action against an unlawful act ” the court is to apply , mutatis mutandis , the provisions of LAW .

CARDINAL . Among NORP legal scholars there is no consensus as to which rights , apart from those enumerated in section CARDINAL of LAW , are to be considered rights of personality . It is , however , common ground that the following rights of natural persons fall into that category : the right to life , the right to physical and mental integrity ( health ) , the right to liberty , the right to reputation and honour , the right to privacy of personal and family life , the right to secrecy of letters and personal manuscripts , the right to personal identity ( in particular the rights to one ’s image , voice and name ) and the moral rights of the author . It would appear that only these rights have so far been interpreted as rights of personality by the NORP courts in the application of section CARDINAL of the former DATE LAW and section CARDINAL of the current DATE LAW . The issue whether other rights guaranteed by the LAW may , at this point , be qualified as rights of personality remains largely disputed .
